intro: Pseudanthistiria hispida, commonly known as the rough-hairy bellflower, is a flowering plant native to certain regions of South America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and leaves. The plant produces bell-shaped, tubular flowers that are typically blue or violet in color. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or streamside habitats. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens, though it can be invasive in some areas.
